Award.AwardTitle: Organizational Workshop for the Future Cyberinfrastructure Consortium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports a two half-day workshop on October 6-7 in Washington, DC, in which the GENI Project Office (GPO) can lead multiple sessions of focused planning for the creation of the Future Cyberinfrastructure Consortium (FCIC). The initial purpose of the FCIC is to provide for the operation, administration, research vision, and governance of the GENI project after the current cooperative agreement between NSF and Raytheon/BBN for the GPO expires in 2017. The intellectual merit of this project is in its goal to coordinate and house a workshop that is the culmination of a GPO-led, ten month long, community-wide inquiry into the future administration and governance of GENI. The workshop will bring together the community of scholars who have committed to participate in continuing the evolution of GENI past the era of the BBN GPO.

The broader impact of this project is in its activities laying the groundwork not just for the continuation of the GENI project, but also for the continued evolution of the ecosystem of consortium, project/administrative office, and physical infrastructure - including network, storage, and computational assets - to a persistent and sustainable national cyberinfrastructure for the support of experimental research in distributed systems, as reflected in the workshop's title: Future Cyberinfrastructure Consortium. In addition to its research mission, the Consortium intends to expand the already wide use of GENI as a teaching tool in secondary schools, colleges, and universities, where it makes the art, science, and technology of distributed systems more accessible to all students, including under-represented ethnic groups, women, and the disabled.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On October 6-7, 2016, Internet2 and the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) Project Office hosted a workshop in Washington, DC, to establish a community-led consortium for advanced research cyberinfrastructure.  It was organized to define the Future Cyberinfrastructure Consortium (FCIC), which will design, deploy, operate, sustain, and evolve an advanced distributed cyberinfrastructure to support education and experimental research addressing grand challenges of society and create a cyberinfrastructure environment to support multiple heterogeneous research testbeds for education and research communities, with the FCIC governed by and acting on behalf of its communities.

Thirty participants attended the workshop, representing 16 institutions in 10 states. The majority represented academic institutions, with representation from non-profit and governmental research organizations.  Goals were to identify a core group of founding members with commitments or intentions of support; agree on an approach for recruiting additional members; and reach consensus on the Consortium’s mission, structure, and operations to begin drafting foundational documents. The workshop included discussion of expectations and deliverables, presentation of position statements and working groups addressing mission, structure, and operations; buy-in, funding, and sustainability; and new member recruitment.  The workshop included group reports and preparation of next steps, milestones, and roadmaps. It also addressed mission and governance; infrastructure design, development, and operation; sustainability models; and next steps.  Discussion also included membership recruitment and initial funding including initial NSF support to refresh installed GENI hardware, partnered with universities committing resources customized to their own campus CI planning. All goals were met: 14 institutions committed to become founding members; several key community segments were identified for targeted recruiting; participants provisionally agreed to an organizational structure; and a small team was assigned to draft foundational documents. Areas for additional discussion were identified, including: clarifying the value proposition for new Consortium members; and detailing the relationship between the Consortium and project offices.

The workshop focused on establishing a consortium whose members would collaborate to design, develop, and operate a next-generation distributed cyberinfrastructure that will support multiple different types of empirical research testbeds available to computer scientists and to related communities for research and education. This cyberinfrastructure will be designed, developed, and operated, by researchers, for researchers. A 5-year model with concurrent initial steps was recommended to allow the FCIC CI to be a major resource for curricular and training activities transforming education across sciences, immersing students in global infrastructure, communities, and challenges.

The workshop final report has been disseminated through a combination of GENI community activities, NSF actions, and larger research community activity. This project is likely to help influence the development and enhancement of cyberinfrastructure strategic planning and deployment within and beyond research-intensive campuses, and create a new consortium that to foster advancements and models for advanced distributed cyberinfrastructure to support education and experimental research. It also will likely have an impact on a broad range of scientific disciplines relying on effectively planned and deployed cyberinfrastructure, and on research involving exchange of large data files, remote collaboration, and data archiving needs.
